ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: I believe Question 1 should have an N/A 7b and 9 do. My "decline" should really be N/A.
1.) We did not have assigned readings, but Jonathan gave an overview of supplementary books we could use.4.) I haven't taken many courses in FES, so I might not be the best judge.
This is a great course and the professor is fantastic.

The professor was just excellent - his enthusiasm, energy, and careful examples made the material, well, come alive. Regrettably if I drifted off I often lost track of where we were (class moved fast) but on good days I learned SO MUCH, which is the mark of a damn good class. My final project was also a delightful experience and I learned a ton.Terrific.

The TAs were not familiar with all of the software platforms and how they work. At some points it was a bit difficult to get help on how to run the packages and analyze the results from consulting the TAs. At the end of the semester, I realized that I had not very effectively been able to keep the multivariate technique apart from one another. Perhaps more clicker review questions (another jeopardy in the middle of the semester - post spring break) would have been useful.
The meaning of each methods and their linkages are not clear to me even now...
The only observation is probably that this semester we had too many people, though the mixture of backgrounds was also interesting.
The flexibility and the "bring your own data" format.
The professor! He keeps it interesting and clear for sometimes a very confusing process.
The professor was, as always, excellent.
Instructor's enthusiasm.
Jonathan was engaging and explained statistics really clearly. Some of the topics I had been introduced to before, but didn't understand until taking the class.
the teacher is really funny
The professor is a fabulous lecturer.
the elucidation of real-world applications to the methods
The professor is amazing -- easily the most competent instructor at F&ES. And he is extremely accessible, with tons of office hours every week.
The professor was enthusiastic and always willing to help. He is a great guy!
Reuning-Scherers is excellent, very clear explanations and great practical approach to statistics. Very approachable and helpful during office hours.
Learning about statistical methods that are common in environmental sciences.
Professor Reuning-Scherer's enthusiasm and jokes was the best part of the course.
Interestig instructor.
The professor! He is great! all the materials he gives are very useful and to the point.

Jonathan makes himself available to help, and really tries to make it fun. Assignments are reasonable and manageable, although to some degree they are too prepackaged to encourage independent thinking.The class greatly facilitates working with your own data, you don't have to follow a set formula.
Lectures introduced material very concisely and clearly.
The jokes! The jokes! More jokes!
JDRS

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: The class was huge. A smaller class would of been nice.
Perhaps a lab session with the whole class.
Sometimes it's confusing to know which methods to use.
The course is a bit fast paced. Perhaps requiring reading or having some review sessions throughout the semester could have aided the retention of information.
Deeper understanding of the methods. Maybe from mathematic perspective?
Maybe another TA if the class is so big, because the professor had to dedicate a lot of time to all of the students.

The class is way too large. 100 students in an advanced graduate-level course is just not acceptable. Something has to be done to keep it under 30, maybe recruit another professor to have a beginners and more advanced version. For a subject this complex that requires so much focus on the details, I was totally lost because of the large lecture format. There's simply no incentive to engage, and I definitely lost out because Jonathan had to teach a rapid lecture style for material that needs to be much more deliberate and interactive.There need to be several more pre-packaged data sets that we can use for the course if we don't have our own. I spent 2 months trying to find an appropriate data set in various databases, which was a waste of time because it is very hard to find datasets in a useable formate. A little more time on data preparation would be helpful.The use of 4 different programs is a bit overkill, although realistic to working with these tools. But honestly, it was very hard to focus on learning one well, when we were expected to jump around a lot. Maybe an ecological and a social science version of the course would be appropriate?Extremely dense and unhelpful reading. There were 6 or 8 books we were advised to look at; impossible to keep track of what was important, or what was useful, so I ended up reading almost nothing.
Less students for more interaction.
Nothing

I personally needed more homework assignments, because that's how I come to understand the material and the large gaps in-between homework assignments feel like vast expanses of staggering through the desert in confusion.

I was able to get the intro stats course waived, and went straight into multivariate. It might have been a bit too steep of a jump without the intro to stats, but then again I also wasn't digging in with vigor to try to refresh myself of the stats I took almost 7 years ago as an undergrad, either. I guess maybe a refresher workshop at the beginning would be good. The "R" tutorial was good, though.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: TA was excellent. Instructor was excellent but hard to get a hold of, he was less than responsive over email.
Excellent. Both the TA and the instructor.
The professor had many office hours scheduled but wasn't great about returning email.
Both the instructors and TA were extremely available and helpful. Excellent at being flexible and wonderful and patient when it comes to explanations.
Both Jonathan and the TAs always seemed to be available. CSSSI seemed to be a good meeting spot.
good
Excellent
everyone always made time. this was one of the best courses I've taken at FES.
Ashley was helpful when I went to her office hours. Somehow, Sanghee managed to have office hours only on Friday mornings and evenings, which didn't seem fair to me.
Very good
Ashley was great as a TA. However, TAs should not be allowed to have office hours 5-9 on Fridays. That's just ridiculous.
The designated office hours (particularly those held in CSSSI) were very helpful. I most often consulted Professor Reuning-Scherer for help.
Instructor is helpful. Never go to TA's office hours.
Amazing, the professor is incredibly responsive, always available and helpful.
big class, but Jonathan made heroic efforts to be available.
Excellent from both. Some of the best I have had as a student
Super available! Super helpful! H++++

Absolutely great. JDRS' extensive office hours were hugely appreciated and he had a great attitude even after seeing students back-to-back-to-back. One of the TA's office hours were quite irregular (like a Friday evening? something like that) and that wasn't very useful, but when the other TA held hours and floated around the CSSSI, that was a good resource and I utilized it.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: Multivariate stats is very important to know for my program, and I would venture, and person's program which remotely relates to reading any type of science articles.
One of my goals is to improve my statistical knowledge and background, and I think this class really helps!
useful
Great overview of important statistical methods that I'll probably use later for research, or for understanding journal articles.
I think every person should take stats in this program. It's really helpful for reading papers and understanding their results.

I think the course fits my program well as all research should be accompanied by statistical analysis. Because of the amounts of surveys that tend to be conducted in environmental management type work, multivariate techniques seem to be particularly relevant to analyzing data.
It should be useful for my research data analysis, but not sure yet.
useful for understanding how to work with social science data.
INdispensible for ecological research
I am a social scientist, and needed to learn how to analyze survey data which requires using multivariate statistics.

I wanted to get a grip on some more stats while at Yale, and I feel like I got that with this class. I'm no expert, but I'd know where to go or what to re-engage with if I needed to draw on some stats know-how in my career.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: It was the most useful of the available options to meet a specific requirement.
To get more quantitative skills under my belt.
To learn multivariate statistical tests.
I use multivariate statistics in my research, so this was a great class for me :)
build data analyst skill
So I could read papers and do analyses.
I took this course because I would like to build a stronger set of skills toperform statistical analysis.
Because I heard it is useful.

Because it is a great continuation of the general stats class in the fall. It is exactly what I needed to analyze my data for my thesis. This type of statistics is hard to learn without a good professor, and this was just the right class for me.
Wanted to know how to analyze social science data.
Need multivariate tools for research projects

I was told in undergrad that it was vital to take more statistics classes no matter what you're studying or what level of life you are in. I still adhere to this advice, therefore statistics fits into my course program by virtue of being inherently useful in helping us all understand the world as we know it.
To fulfill a requirement for my degree program
To bolster my quantitative background, career-strategic-thinking

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes.
Yes.
Yes.
I enjoyed the section on Manova and the PCA section helps me to understand techniques that I read in papers. However, I failed to see the use of many of the other techniques.
Moderately yes; honestly, if I took the homework assignments more seriously, I would have learned more.
Yup. It was great!
Yes
yes
Yes
yes
Definitely.
Yes
Yes.
Yes.
Not that much.
Yes, it did.

No, it was much too large of a class, and I'm inevitably lost in a large lecture format for material that is this dense. I managed to get through the homework, but I don't feel I understand anything at the end of the semester. So it was a bit of a waste for me...
Exceeded my expectations.
Yes
Do you do any multivariate analyses of student responses to these course evaluations? Because that would be hilarious, and you should use the results as an example in class next year.
Yes, and it was a reminder of how challenging the area of statistics can be!

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes
I got a lot of out it, about on par with what I expected.
Yes.
Yes.
There were some things I will use a lot, some things I will go back to my notes for in a few years, and some things I may never use-- but overall, I think it will be helpful!
yes
Yes
Yes
Yes
Yes.
Yes.
I got confused many times....
Yes, I did.
Not really.
Yes
Sure whynot.
Yes. I was also happy to become familiar with some statistical packages (SPSS, primarily)

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Complementary skill sets.
Very very helpful for homework. I highly suggest working in a group.
Group work was great. It helped us understand better and share different ideas and strengths.
very helpful
advantages:lighter course loaddisadvantages:risk of group members not doing their share
It was helpful to have people to talk ideas through with and get through sticking points.
Group work was very advantageous as it is extremely helpful to discuss statistical results with another person to correctly interpret them.
The group work was not quite well. People don't understand the methods and lose interests in teamwork.
No disadvantages, all great.
Useful so you don't waste time clicking random buttons, and your friends can help keep you on task. Essential to work in a group in this class, unless you are somewhat of a renegade stats genius.
Well, I worked in a group of 3 for homeworks and the final project. It was a great setup and good for both helping explain things to one another and for moral support.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Keep up with the homework.
Use your own data even if will require more work as this will pay off in the end.
Start the HW early and go to office hours to ask questions if you get stuck. Don't spend too much time trying to figure out code. Better to go in and ask.
Start your homework early and go in to office hours!
Use a dataset that is of interest to you!
use the software yourself
Spend time doing your homework thoroughly and read Multivariate Statistics for the Environmental Sciences.
Start off with a dataset that you will use for your final project. You can use the same techniques for homework and the final, thereby saving a lot of time.
Take notes on the notes that he gives.
I would advise the students to read the recommended reading material alongside the course. I found this extremely helpful to understanding the material.
Read the materials carefully every time, or you may get lost.
Read all the class notes, use the TA and professor hours, and practice a lot in the stats lab.

Find a data set very quickly, because time will fly by. Use Jonathan's office hours. Don't do the reading, it doesn't help at all. If your stats is really rusty, take a smaller, more basic refresher course to catch up; that way you can get a lot out of this course, because Jonathan's offers a lot of very advanced material and support.
Spend time not just doing homework, but understanding what the techniques are accomplishing.

I would have gotten more out of the class if I had participated in group work and forced my peers to help me master the material. I was horribly individualistic and refused offers to join groups that were analyzing data I wasn't interested in, which ultimately meant that I learned less struggling through the dataset I was interested in.
If you're not looking to become a statistician or whiz, pick a dataset that isn't too unwieldy so you can focus on the tools and not your data.
